user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of calculate_add_nonce:
```c
static bool
calculate_add_nonce (struct MHD_Connection *const connection,
                     uint64_t timestamp,
                     const char *realm,
                     size_t realm_len,
                     struct DigestAlgorithm *da,
                     char *nonce)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *const daemon = MHD_get_master (connection->daemon);
  struct MHD_NonceNc *nn;
  const size_t nonce_size = NONCE_STD_LEN (digest_get_size (da));
  bool ret;

  mhd_assert (! da->hashing);
  mhd_assert (MAX_DIGEST_NONCE_LENGTH >= nonce_size);
  mhd_assert (0 != nonce_size);

  calculate_nonce (timestamp,
                   connection->rq.http_mthd,
                   connection->rq.method,
                   daemon->digest_auth_random,
                   daemon->digest_auth_rand_size,
                   connection->addr,
                   (size_t) connection->addr_len,
                   connection->rq.url,
                   connection->rq.url_len,
                   connection->rq.headers_received,
                   realm,
                   realm_len,
                   daemon->dauth_bind_type,
                   da,
                   nonce);

#ifdef MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR
  if (digest_ext_error (da))
    return false;
#endif /* MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR */

  if (0 == daemon->nonce_nc_size)
    return false;

  /* Sanity check for values */
  mhd_assert (MAX_DIGEST_NONCE_LENGTH == NONCE_STD_LEN (MAX_DIGEST));

  nn = daemon->nnc + get_nonce_nc_idx (daemon->nonce_nc_size,
                                       nonce,
                                       nonce_size);

  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->nnc_lock);
  if (is_slot_available (nn, timestamp, nonce, nonce_size))
  {
    memcpy (nn->nonce,
            nonce,
            nonce_size);
    nn->nonce[nonce_size] = 0;  /* With terminating zero */
    nn->nc = 0;
    nn->nmask = 0;
    ret = true;
  }
  else
    ret = false;
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&daemon->nnc_lock);

  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I reviewed the function for use of known compiler/language extensions that are explicitly documented as extensions (examples checked: identifiers with leading double underscores or reserved compiler names, GCC/Clang __attribute__ or __asm__ tokens, typeof/__typeof__, statement expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, inline assembly, builtin extension operators, asm labels, GNU compound literals used as expressions, trailing comma in macro-only contexts that are extensions, and other vendor-specific tokens). The code uses only standard C constructs visible here: function-level static, pointer and const qualifiers, casts (size_t), standard integer types (uint64_t, size_t), bool (from C99/C11 stdbool.h), preprocessor conditionals (#ifdef), and standard library calls (memcpy). No __attribute__, __asm__, __typeof__, statement-expressions, nested functions, or other compiler-specific extensions appear in the provided snippet. Note: macros called here (mhd_assert, MHD_mutex_lock_chk_, calculate_nonce, etc.) could potentially expand to extension usage, but those expansions are not present in the shown code; per the rule you requested, I flagged only explicit language/compiler extensions present in the provided code fragment — none were found.
